title: Contemporary Principles of African Indigenous Entrepreneurship
xlist: Same As: MGT 615, section 01
description: This practice-oriented course explores the history of indigenous African entrepreneurship and shows how many of the so-called modern breakthrough models/concepts we hear about today have always been embedded in traditional African indigenous entrepreneurship practices. The course has therefore been designed to help us learn from the past to create a better future. It provides students with the entrepreneurial skills required to identify value-creating opportunities and to build, sustain, and grow a successful business in today’s VUCA world. We define success as creating significant value for the customer and connect this to solving social problems while making financial returns. One of the main reasons why businesses fail is the absence of a sense of purpose and a sole focus on profit. Being purpose-driven happens to be the secret to the success and wealth enjoyed by the world’s richest entrepreneurs. The course opens students’ eyes to the positive relationship between impact and profit, demonstrating how business can effectively be used to create shared prosperity, so badly needed in this time of huge income disparities that have resulted in an unsustainable world under the global threat of terrorism. Students learn how to start impact-driven ventures with little or no resources and still be profitable. Indeed, doing good and doing well (financially) can be a lot more impactful and profitable than doing well financially and then doing good, which is the traditional CSR model. Students are guided through the process of starting and nurturing a business venture that can continue to grow beyond the tenure of the course. Also MGT 615.
